author: pdp
content: Yahoo PIPEs is down for now. Give Yahoo some time to fix the mess, then try the POCs.

author: pdp
content: Yahoo PIPEs is back. POCs work.

author: Acidus
content:
HAHA! That's awesome! I did some work against TinyURL a year or so back with TinyDisk (http://www.msblabs.org/tinydisk). Glad to see someone else using it as a data storage system!

Go pdp!

author: pdp
content: To me, the Web is one gigantic operating system with hundreds of APIs and syscalls. The browser is our shell from where we can access the WebOS features. TinyURL, although just URL shrinking service, can be used as a storage mechanism as you pointed out long time ago. However, I seriously doubt that no one has thought that this functionality will be available to JavaScript as well. Similar types of setups can significantly increase the attack surface of web based malware written entirely in JavaScript.

author: pdp
content: Unfortunately, PIPEs is down again. I suspect Yahoo has some serious problems. I have never seen anything like that before.

author: MacGyveR
content: Have you thought of implementing redundancy on the tinyFS by using other such services in a type of software raid manner. striping or mirroring could be done here, giving potenial worms etc. a fallback if one service blocks them.

author: pdp
content: yes, it is possible and very probable that it will happen!

author: pdp
content: Due to the fact that Yahoo is constantly changing their services, you might not be able to successfully execute this POC. At the time of publishing, the POC was working successfully.
